key_insight: eMOSAIC combines multimodal molecular and protein information with per-sample out-of-distribution (OOD) uncertainty estimation to substantially improve binding affinity predictions for compounds that act on multiple targets.
problem_solved: Predicting binding affinities in polypharmacology is hard because models face diverse chemical–protein contexts and fail silently on OOD examples; this work addresses unreliable predictions and lack of calibrated, individual uncertainty estimates for each compound–target pair.
method: Multimodal representation: fuse chemical (small-molecule) and protein (sequence/structure) features to capture interaction context.
OOD-aware individual uncertainty quantification: estimate per-sample predictive uncertainty to identify when predictions may be unreliable or out-of-distribution.
Model/validation pipeline: integrate calibrated uncertainty into affinity prediction scoring and benchmark against standard baselines across polypharmacological test sets.
impact: Provides practitioners with more trustworthy affinity predictions and actionable uncertainty signals for screening and lead prioritization, improving decision-making and reducing costly experimental follow-ups in drug discovery.
visual_elements: Pipeline diagram: multimodal inputs (molecule + protein) → eMOSAIC model → affinity prediction + per-sample uncertainty
Scatter plot: predicted vs. true affinities with points colored/sized by predicted uncertainty to highlight OOD failures
Bar/line chart: performance and calibration improvement vs. baselines (RMSE, AUPR, calibration error)
Network schematic: example polypharmacology map showing one compound connecting to multiple targets with confidence annotations
paper_title: Multimodal out-of-distribution individual uncertainty quantification enhances binding affinity prediction for polypharmacology
paper_authors: Amitesh Badkul, Li Xie, Shuo Zhang, Lei Xie
